commitResults.messageTitle: Update value proposition for developer's guide
Add find by tags functionality to Find command
commitResults.messageBody:
The current find command only searches persons by name, limiting search flexibility for tutors who want to search up students with important tags.

Users who tag their contacts cannot easily filter and find persons based on those tags, making tag organization less useful.

Let's enhance the find command to support tag-based searching:
*Create TagContainsKeywordsPredicate to filter persons by tags
*Update FindCommandParser to detect t/ prefix for tag search mode
*Modify FindCommand to accept generic Predicate for flexibility
*Add tests for tag search functionality
*Update User Guide and Developer Guide with examples and implementation details

Using a separate predicate class maintains consistency with the existing NameContainsKeywordsPredicate pattern and allows FindCommand to remain flexible for future search enhancements.

The implementation uses ArgumentTokenizer to detect the t/ prefix defaulting to name search when absent. This makes it quicker when users want to search for names

Also fixed build.gradle mainClassName from seedu.address.Main to tutortrack.Main to resolve application startup error.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add test case for find tags functionality

commitResults.messageBody: change add and edit command in userguide to accommodate to new fields
Add LessonProgress and trivial tests for v1.2

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix: Add missing required fields to test JSON files
commitResults.messageBody:
- Add subjectLevel, dayTime, and cost fields to test Person objects
- Fix double semicolon in PersonBuilder.java
- Ensures tests validate intended fields rather than fail on missing new fields"

commitResults.messageTitle: Ui: align contact card and cli with MVP design
Remove email field for add and edit commands
commitResults.messageBody:
Email field is not needed for the tutor tracking application as contact
can be handled through phone numbers alone. Having an unnecessary field adds complexity to data entry and maintenance.

The email field is not being used in the core functionality of tracking tutoring sessions and student information.

Let's remove the email field from:
* Person model class and all its references
* Add and Edit commands and their parsers
* UI display components (PersonCard and FXML)
* JSON storage and serialization
* Messages formatter
* Sample data utility
* Parser utility methods

This simplifies the data model and reduces the required fields for
adding/editing persons. Phone number remains as the primary contact
method.

Note: Test cases will be updated in a subsequent commit.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update test cases to match removed email field
Update user guide to remove mentions of emails
Create jar file and update version to v1.3
Change to prefix-based name search for find
commitResults.messageBody:
Name searches currently require full-word matches, which limits usability when users only remember the beginning of a name (e.g., "Jo" for "John" or "Joseph").

Prefix-based matching is more natural for users as it aligns with search behaviors in contact lists.

Let's replace full-word matching with token-based prefix matching to improve find command usability.

This commit:
* adds containsPrefixIgnoreCase() to StringUtil
* updates NameContainsKeywordsPredicate to use prefix logic
* updates command documentation and examples
* updates tests to cover prefix matching scenarios

commitResults.messageTitle: Add ranked prefix search for names
commitResults.messageBody:
Find command shows matched persons but does not prioritize results by how well a name matches the query.
Users often type partial first names and expect those to appear before last-name matches.

Let's add token-based prefix matching with ranking for name searches.
Through this, first name matches are ranked before other last name  matches.
This improves relevance of search results.

Changes:
* NameContainsKeywordsPredicate: add ranking logic
* FindCommand: support optional comparator
* ModelManager: wrap FilteredList with SortedList
* Model: add updateFilteredPersonList(predicate, comparator)
* FindCommandParser: apply ranking for name searches

Example:
For the keyword "Al", "Alex Tan" (first-token match) should rank above "John Alexander" (other-token match).
Add developer guide and user guide for add plan and add progress

commitResults.messageTitle: Add find by day functionality with time sorting
commitResults.messageBody:
The find command currently only supports searching by name and tags.
Users cannot easily view all lessons scheduled for a specific day.

Tutors often need to see their schedule for a particular day (e.g
all Monday lessons) to plan their day and identify time slots.

Let's,
* Add LessonDayPredicate to filter persons by lesson day
* Update FindCommandParser to handle d/ prefix for day searches
* Implement case-insensitive day matching
* Sort filtered and display results by lesson time (earliest to latest)
* Add comprehensive unit tests for the new predicate and sorting

The day-based search uses case-insensitive matching to improve
usability. Automatic time-based sorting is applied to day searches
because chronological ordering is the natural way tutors would want
to view their daily schedule.

Usage: find d/Monday

commitResults.messageTitle: Update user guide and developer guide for find by day
Add more test cases for find by day
Update command summary in user guide

commitResults.messageBody: Hot reload for view lessons add

commitResults.messageTitle: LessonWindow: Implement hot reload for lesson data updates
commitResults.messageBody:
The LessonWindow does not update automatically when lesson progress or
lesson plans are modified via editprogress/editplan commands.

This occurs because these commands create new Person objects to replace
the old ones in the model. The LessonWindow's event listeners remain
attached to the old Person objects, so changes to the new objects are
not detected.

Let's,
* Add a currentPerson field in LessonWindow to track the displayed person
* Remove the event listener approach (ineffective due to object replacement)
* Add a refresh() method that fetches updated person data from the model
* Update MainWindow to call refresh() after every command execution

This approach works for all commands of addprogress, editprogress, addplan,
editplan and only refreshes when the window is visible.

commitResults.messageTitle: Generate jar and update version code

commitResults.messageBody:
Users currently cannot delete lesson plans once they are added. They can
only edit existing plans using the editplan command. This is problematic
when a plan is no longer needed or was added by mistake.

Adding a delete functionality gives users more flexibility when managing
lesson plans. Therefore, improving the application's usability.

Let's,
* Add DeletePlanCommand class that deletes plans by date
* Add DeletePlanCommandParser to parse "deleteplan INDEX DATE" format
* Add removeLessonPlanByDate() method to Person class
* Use the new command in AddressBookParser
* Include some logging, assertions, and defensive programming
* Provide detailed error messages for invalid dates (format vs values)

The command follows the INDEX DATE format (e.g., deleteplan 1 2025-10-15)
to maintain consistency with other lesson-related commands that require
an index parameter.

The implementation creates a new Person object rather than directly
mutating the existing one to comply with the Model's setPerson() API
and maintain proper Observable list updates for the UI.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add comprehensive test cases for DeletePlanCommand

commitResults.messageBody: Add tests for lesson plan storage

Users need a way to remove incorrect lesson progress entries from
their students' records.

Currently, users can only add and edit lesson progress but cannot delete
them. This creates clutter when progress entries are added with wrong
dates and need to be removed.

Let's add a new deleteprogress command that allows users to delete a
lesson progress entry by specifying the student index and date.

The implementation:
* Add removeLessonProgressByDate() method to Person class to support
  progress deletion
* Create DeleteProgressCommand following the immutable pattern used in
  DeletePlanCommand for consistency
* Create DeleteProgressCommandParser to parse user input in the format
  "deleteprogress INDEX DATE"
* Register the command in AddressBookParser to enable command routing

This maintains code consistency with other operations (e.g., deleteplan)
and adheres to the immutability principle for Person objects.

commitResults.messageTitle: Create DeleteLessonItemCommand class and update tests
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, DeleteProgressCommand and DeletePlanCommand have excessive
lines of duplicated code, violating DRY principle and design principles.
Also, the test cases are not updated.

Let's
* Create abstract DeleteLessonItemCommand with common execute() logic
* Refactor both commands to extend base class
* Create new methods in Person class to encapsulate copy and remove
  logic
* Update tests to use new Person methods
* Update test cases for deleteProgressCommand

This implementation eliminates Law of Demeter violations and follows
tell, don't ask principle and ensures that code is not excessively
duplicated. Commands tells Person what to do rather than
querying and manipulating the data.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update user guide for delete progress
Show error when find returns no result
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, when user uses the find command if there are no names
within the contact book, the message of 0 person listed will show and
the list will clear all contacts. This could make the user experience
bad for the user given that all the contacts are cleared and the user
has to retype the intended search parameters.

Let's
- Ensure that there are search results before applying the filter
- Throw CommandException when no matching persons are found
- Keep the current list visible instead of clearing to an empty list
- Add MESSAGE_NO_PERSON_FOUND constant in Messages
- Preserve command text in input box for easy retry

This improves UX by allowing users to easily modify their search
criteria instead of retyping the entire command. The list will
also not be cleared unnecessarily.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update test cases for find command
Update user guide and developers guide
Improved error messages for deleteplan and progress
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, when a user tries to deleteplan or progress from an invalid
index it will give the error message invalid command format. Also, if
the index is a value larger than what an integer can represent the
error message will default to invalid command format.

Let's
- Add explicit overflow handling in ParserUtil.parseIndex() to catch
  numbers exceeding Integer.MAX_VALUE
- Update DeletePlanCommandParser to give correct error messages
  instead of using a generic "Invalid command format!" message
- Update DeleteProgressCommandParser to give correct error messages
  instead of using a generic "Invalid command format!" message
- Replace technical jargon "non-zero unsigned integer" with a more
  user-friendly message in ParserUtil: "Invalid index. Please use a
  valid number from the displayed list (e.g., 1, 2, 3)."

These changes improve UX for non-technical users (tutors) by providing
clearer, more actionable error messages that identify the specific issue
while still showing usage examples.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update developer guide for deleteprogress feature
Update find command to give clearer error message
Improve date validation for deleteplan command
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, when user inputs invalid days in the month the error message
shown is too generic and does not match the one created for addprogress.

Let's
- Add more specific error messages for deleteplan to let users know
if they have swapped the dates and month, keyed in a invalid date or
used an invalid month.
- Add ParserUtil.parseDate() method to centralize date validation logic
- Refactor DeletePlanCommandParser to use ParserUtil.parseDate()
- Add validation for invalid day-month combinations (e.g., Feb 31, Apr 31)
- Update User Guide to document enhanced date validation
- Update Developer Guide test cases for deleteplan command

This fix ensures that deleteplan rejects invalid dates like 2025-02-31
and provides clearer error messages for date validation failures. Also,
this fix helps to reduce deuplicated code for the date parser for
deleteplan and deleteprogress commands which needs the same checks.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update test cases for deleteplan command
Add test cases to increase code coverage
Update deleteprogress command to show clearer error messages
Add and update test cases for deleteprogresscommandparser
Update user guide and developer guide for deleteprogress
Add day validation for find d/ command
commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, if the user uses find command of find d/Tomorrow, where
tomorrow is an invalid day. The error message would be Contact list
is unchanged: No students match your search criteria. This error
message can be clearer to let the user know why it is wrong.

- Add MESSAGE_INVALID_DAY constant to Messages.java for consistent error
messaging
- Implement ParserUtil.parseDay() to validate day of week input
using regex
- Update FindCommandParser to validate day parameter before creating
predicate
- Add comprehensive test cases for invalid day inputs (abbreviations,
typos, invalid names)
- Update User Guide with validation requirements and error examples
- Update Developer Guide with implementation details and validation
logic

The find d/ command now only accepts full day names (Monday-Sunday) and
rejects abbreviations (e.g., "Mon"), typos (e.g., "Mondayy"), and invalid
inputs like "Tomorrow" or "1" with a clear error message.

commitResults.messageTitle: Find command to search from full list
Update user guide url in help page
Improve error handling for find command
commitResults.messageBody:
Previously, FindCommandParser silently ignored the preamble when a
prefix was present (e.g., "find john t/exams" would ignore "john" and
only search for tags). This fix adds validation to reject commands that
have both a preamble and a prefix, following the same pattern used in
AddCommandParser.

Let's
- Add preamble validation in FindCommandParser.parse()
- Add test cases for preamble with tag, day, and subject prefixes

This ensures that user receives error messages instead of expecting
the search to succeed.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor: Extract common index-date parsing logic to ParserUtil
commitResults.messageBody:
Eliminate duplicate code between DeletePlanCommandParser and
DeleteProgressCommandParser by adding parseIndexAndDate() helper
method and IndexDatePair class to ParserUtil.

This reduces duplication while maintaining the same functionality
and following the established Command pattern architecture.
Dg & diagram update for edit plan feature

Update user stories and value proposition
Update user and developer guide for find by name
Improve error message for invalid day and update UG

commitResults.messageBody:
Currently, users need to scroll to view the error messages.

Let's enable text wrapping so users do not need to scroll horizontally.

This improves the user experience.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update user guide introduction and formatting
Find command: improve error handling and code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
The find command silently ignores multiple and duplicate prefix usage
(e.g., find t/tag s/subject or find t/tag t/tag), making it difficult
for users to understand unexpected search behavior.

Users need clear, actionable error messages that explain what went wrong
and how to fix it. Additionally, some error messages are scattered
inline rather than centralized.

Let's,
* add validation to reject multiple search prefixes with a clear error
* add validation to reject duplicate prefix usage with specific guidance
* centralize find-related error messages in Messages.java
* optimize FindCommandParser by extracting error Map to class constant
* update UserGuide to document all find error scenarios with examples

The Map-based approach for duplicate validation is preferred over
repetitive if-statements because it's more maintainable and follows
the DRY principle. Error messages are moved to Messages.java to
maintain consistency with the existing codebase structure.

Each search type section in UserGuide now includes relevant error
examples immediately after the usage examples, making it easier for
users to troubleshoot issues in context.
